title: Your Favourite Digital Foundries?
content:
**¶ Find the ritual question concerning the foundries that you admire and purchase from.**

Back in the 1990's, the first foundry that I was hooked on was  
 [House Industries](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713110157/http:/www.houseind.com/).  
I discovered it by reading a newspaper in which I noticed [_House Gothic_](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713110157/http:/www.houseind.com/fonts/housegothic23).

Let's hear from you…
author: Fournier

comments.content:
I don’t licence fonts any more, but I used to.  
I was impressed with FontFont back in the day (c.1990), in particular the classic vibe of their black + PMS 115 direct mail ﬂyers and brochures.  
So, no surprise that they published my ﬁrst digital type design, in 1994.

I can't think of another foundry as culturally significant as Monokrom.  
 [https://monokrom.no/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713110157/https:/monokrom.no/ "https://monokrom.no/")

hhp

to Nick: why did you stop?  
to Hrant: could you explain more why Monokrom is culturally significant.  
thanks!

They make highly usable fonts that bravely introduce new –or rare– ideas. Virtually all foundries are highly formulaic.

hhp

I meant license from others, as in the OP’s “…purchase [licences] from…”, not licence to.

So I have changed from licensing fonts _from_ others, which I did in the early days of digital, when I was working as an art director and graphic designer, to licensing fonts _to_ others, since I have been publishing fonts full time.
